title: College football coaches vs. governors: Who makes more money?
text:
CLOSE USA TODAY Sports' Paul Myerberg breaks down the latest Amway Coaches Poll. USA TODAY

Governors are, in theory, the most powerful people in their states – or, at the very least, the most visible figureheads. They're responsible for implementing policies, managing budgets and signing bills into law.

They also earn only a fraction of what public school Football Bowl Subdivision coaches earn.

According to USA TODAY Sports' annual review of coaches compensation – and governor salary data compiled by the nonpartisan, nonprofit Council of State Governments – governors will make about 6%, on average, of what the highest-paid public school coach in their state will make in 2019.

Governor salaries range from $90,000 to $201,000, according to the data, while coaching compensation at the FBS level typically exceeds seven figures, including salaries north of $5 million for elite coaches at Power Five schools.

Clemson's Dabo Swinney, for example, leads the pack this year with a total compensation of $9.32 million. South Carolina Gov. Henry McMaster, by comparison, will make a little more than 1% of that amount – about $106,000.

It's important to note that governors are elected public servants while college football coaches are employees in a free market ecosystem that allows different schools to compete for their services.

Here's a look at the highest-paid coach in each of the 41 states that have an FBS football program and the governor salaries in those states.

description: Governors may hold the power, but college football coaches are by far the highest-paid of the public employees. Check out a state-by-state comparison.
